00020 #define NACL_ARRAY_SIZE_UNSAFE(arr) ((sizeof arr)/sizeof arr[0])
00021 
00022 /*
00023  * ASSERT_IS_ARRAY(arr) generates a somewhat opaque compile-time
00024  * error if arr is a non-array pointer.  This protects against
00025  * situations where one writes code like:
00026  *
00027  * foo.h:  struct Foo { char buffer[BUFFERSIZE]; size_t sofar; ... };
00028  *
00029  * foo.c:  got = read(d, fp->buffer + fp->sofar, sizeof fp->buffer - fp->sofar);
00030  *         if (-1 == got) { ... }
00031  *         fp->sofar += got;
00032  *
00033  *         for (ix = 0; ix < sizeof arr/sizeof arr[0]; ++ix) { ... }
00034  *
00035  * and have it break and create a security problem when somebody later
00036  * changes Foo to dynamically allocate buffer, viz,
00037  *
00038  * foo.h:  struct Foo { char *buffer; size_t sofar; ... };
00039  *
00040  * and now sizeof fp->buffer is 4 or 8, with size_t (type of sizeof)
00041  * being unsigned, when fp->sofar is larger than 4 or 8, getting an
00042  * enormous maximum read size being used.  Such bugs can remain
00043  * undiscovered when conforming implementations of protocol engines
00044  * are used where the actual amount sent is small and would never
00045  * cause a buffer overflow, but an adversarial implementation would be
00046  * able to clobber the heap.  The solution is to write:
00047  *
00048  * foo.c:  NACL_ASSERT_IS_ARRAY(fp->buffer);
00049  *         got = read(d, fp->buffer + fp->sofar, sizeof fp->buffer - fp->sofar);
00050  *         if (-1 == got) { ... }
00051  *         fp->sofar += got;
00052  *
00053  *         for (ix = 0; ix < NACL_ARRAY_SIZE(arr); ++ix) { ... }
00054  *
00055  * and when foo.h is modified, it will generate a compile-time error
00056  * alerting the engineer makin the change that the read code will need to
00057  * be modified.
00058  *
00059  * NB: The -pedantic flag is REQUIRED for the C version to catch the
00060  *     error.  No special warning flags are required for the C++
00061  *     version to work.
00062  */
00063 
00064 #ifdef __cplusplus
00065 /*
00066  * C++ version is taken from chrome's basictypes.h, and renamed to
00067  * avoid collision in case of multiple includes.  NACL_ARRAY_SIZE
00068  * relies on template matching failure if the argument is not an
00069  * array.
00070  */
00071 template <typename T, size_t N>
00072 char (&NaClArraySizeHelper(T (&array)[N]))[N];
00073 
00074 #ifndef _MSC_VER
00075 template <typename T, size_t N>
00076 char (&NaClArraySizeHelper(const T (&array)[N]))[N];
00077 #endif  /* _MSC_VER */
00078 
00079 #define NACL_ARRAY_SIZE(array) (sizeof(NaClArraySizeHelper(array)))
00080 
00081 /*
00082  * Dead code elimination will get rid of this if there are no
00083  * compile-time errors generated by ARRAY_SIZE.
00084  */
00085 #define NACL_ASSERT_IS_ARRAY(array)                     \
00086   do {                                                  \
00087     char __array__[NACL_ARRAY_SIZE(array)];             \
00088     if (0 == sizeof __array__) {                        \
00089       abort();                                          \
00090     }                                                   \
00091   } while (0)
00092 
00093 #else  /* __cplusplus */
00094 
00095 /*
00096  * The C version uses the fact that __builtin_types_compatible_p can
00097  * be used to discriminate between T * and T *const.  (Note that this
00098  * difference is not a top-level qualifier difference as mentioned in
00099  * the gcc info node; that would apply to T * versus T const *.)  In
00100  * the assertion statement version (NACL_ASSERT_IS_ARRAY), we use this
00101  * to allocate an array, and ISO C forbids a zero-sized array.  In the
00102  * expression version (ARRAY_SIZE), we assign to a global void * --
00103  * assigning a zero is fine, but assigning a 1 results in a warning
00104  * that making a pointer from an integer is verboten.  When ARRAY_SIZE
00105  * is used in a loop control context, e.g.,
00106  *
00107  * for (ix = 0; ix < ARRAY_SIZE(arr); ++ix) { ... }
00108  *
00109  * with -O the optimizer recognizes that the store can be moved out of
00110  * the loop, so the performance impact should be minimal.
00111  */
00112 # if __GNUC__
00113 #  define NACL_ASSERT_IS_ARRAY(arr)                           \
00114   do {                                                        \
00115     char __is_array__[!__builtin_types_compatible_p(          \
00116         __typeof__(&arr[0]),                                  \
00117         __typeof__(arr))];                                    \
00118     /* dead code, but gets rid of unused-variable warnings */ \
00119     if (0 == sizeof __is_array__) {                           \
00120       abort();                                                \
00121     }                                                         \
00122   } while (0)
00123 
00124 static inline void *NaClArrayCheckHelper(void *arg) {
00125   /*
00126    * Doing runtime checks is not really necessary -- this code is in
00127    * fact unreachable code that gets optimized out when used with the
00128    * NACL_ARRAY_SIZE definition below.
00129    *
00130    * The runtime check is only useful when the build system is using
00131    * the inappropriate flags (e.g., missing -pedantic -Werror or
00132    * -pedantic-error), in which case instead of a compile-time error,
00133    * we'd get a runtime error.
00134    */
00135   if (NULL != arg) {
00136     abort();
00137   }
00138   return arg;
00139 }
00140 
00141 #  define NACL_ARRAY_SIZE(arr)                                         \
00142   (NaClArrayCheckHelper(                                               \
00143       __builtin_types_compatible_p(__typeof__(&arr[0]),                \
00144                                    __typeof__(arr))),                  \
00145   NACL_ARRAY_SIZE_UNSAFE(arr))
00146 # else  /* __GNUC__ */
00147 
00148 /*
00149  * Not gcc.  So far, we only compile NaCl under gcc and visual studio,
00150  * but if/when a new compiler is introduced that's capable of doing
00151  * compile-time checking (or we figure out how to do it w/ visual
00152  * studio), check for those compilers here, and enable the
00153  * corresponding compile-failure tests in
00154  * src/trusted/service_runtime/build.scons.
00155  */
00156 
00157 #  define NACL_ASSERT_IS_ARRAY(arr)
00158 #  define NACL_ARRAY_SIZE(arr) NACL_ARRAY_SIZE_UNSAFE(arr)
00159 # endif  /* __GNUC__ */
00160 #endif  /* __cplusplus */
00161 
00162 /*
00163  * NACL_ASSERT_IS_POINTER(arr) generates a somewhat opaque compile-time
00164  * error if lvalue is not a pointer lvalue but is instead an actual
00165  * array (which is a T * const object).  This is complementary to
00166  * NACL_ASSERT_IS_ARRAY.
00167  */
00168 #define NACL_ASSERT_IS_POINTER(ptr) do { if (0) { ++ptr; } } while (0)
00169 
00170 /*
00171  * NACL_ASSERT_SAME_SIZE(t1, t2) verifies that the two types have the same size
00172  * (as reported by sizeof).  When the check fails it generates a somewhat
00173  * opaque warning, mitigated by the variable's name.
00174  *
00175  * Examples:
00176  *   NACL_ASSERT_SAME_SIZE(void *, char *);  // Likely to succeed!
00177  *   NACL_ASSERT_SAME_SIZE(char, long);  // Unlikely to succeed
00178  */
00179 #define NACL_ASSERT_SAME_SIZE(t1, t2) \
00180   do { char tested_types_are_not_the_same_size[sizeof(t1) == sizeof(t2)]; \
00181        (void) tested_types_are_not_the_same_size; } while (0)
00182 
00183 
00184 /*****************************************************************************
00185  * MAX/MIN macros for integral types                                         *
00186  ****************************************************************************/
00187 
00188 /*
00189  * For NACL_MAX_VAL, T must be a type where u ## T is the unsigned
00190  * version of the type.
00191  *
00192  * These macros rely on -1 being signed extended to the width of T (or
00193  * u ## T), and on two's complement representation of integers.
00194  *
00195  * Generally, stdint.h's INT16_MAX etc can be used, but these are
00196  * useful for macros that take a type parameter and need the max or
00197  * min value for the type, since then the macro would not have to also take
00198  * the max or min value as additional parameter(s).
00199  */
00200 #define NACL_UMAX_VAL(T)  ((T) -1)
00201 #define NACL_MAX_VAL(T)   ((T) (((u ## T) -1) >> 1))
00202 #define NACL_UMIN_VAL(T)  ((T) 0)
00203 #define NACL_MIN_VAL(T)   ((T) ~NACL_MAX_VAL(T))
00204 
00205

00208  ****************************************************************************/

00210 #define NACL_NANOS_PER_MICRO          1000
00211 #define NACL_100_NANOS_PER_MILLI      (10 * 1000)
00212 #define NACL_NANOS_PER_MILLI          (1000 * 1000)
00213 #define NACL_MICROS_PER_UNIT          (1000 * 1000)
00214 #define NACL_MILLIS_PER_UNIT          1000
00215 #define NACL_UNIT_CONVERT_ROUND(v, m) (((v) + (m) - 1)/(m))

00221 #ifdef __cplusplus
00222 /*
00223  * A macro to disallow the copy constructor and operator= functions
00224  * This should be used in the private: declarations for a class
00225  */
00226 #define NACL_DISALLOW_COPY_AND_ASSIGN(TypeName) \
00227     TypeName(const TypeName&);                  \
00228     void operator=(const TypeName&)
00229 
00230 /* A macro to use in place of unimplemented sections of code */
00231 #define NACL_UNIMPLEMENTED()                                       \
00232     fprintf(stderr, "%s:%d: unimplemented\n", __FILE__, __LINE__); \
00233     exit(1);
00234 
00235 /* A macro to use to detect when control reaches a statement it should not. */
00236 #define NACL_NOTREACHED()                                                  \
00237     fprintf(stderr, "%s:%d: should not reach here\n", __FILE__, __LINE__); \
00238     exit(1);
00239 
00240 // nacl_bit_cast<Dest,Source> is a template function that implements the
00241 // equivalent of "*reinterpret_cast<Dest*>(&source)".  We need this in
00242 // very low-level functions like the protobuf library and fast math
00243 // support.
00244 //
00245 //   float f = 3.14159265358979;
00246 //   int i = nacl_bit_cast<int32>(f);
00247 //   // i = 0x40490fdb
00248 //
00249 // The classical address-casting method is:
00250 //
00251 //   // WRONG
00252 //   float f = 3.14159265358979;            // WRONG
00253 //   int i = * reinterpret_cast<int*>(&f);  // WRONG
00254 //
00255 // The address-casting method actually produces undefined behavior
00256 // according to ISO C++ specification section 3.10 -15 -.  Roughly, this
00257 // section says: if an object in memory has one type, and a program
00258 // accesses it with a different type, then the result is undefined
00259 // behavior for most values of "different type".
00260 //
00261 // This is true for any cast syntax, either *(int*)&f or
00262 // *reinterpret_cast<int*>(&f).  And it is particularly true for
00263 // conversions betweeen integral lvalues and floating-point lvalues.
00264 //
00265 // The purpose of 3.10 -15- is to allow optimizing compilers to assume
00266 // that expressions with different types refer to different memory.  gcc
00267 // 4.0.1 has an optimizer that takes advantage of this.  So a
00268 // non-conforming program quietly produces wildly incorrect output.
00269 //
00270 // The problem is not the use of reinterpret_cast.  The problem is type
00271 // punning: holding an object in memory of one type and reading its bits
00272 // back using a different type.
00273 //
00274 // The C++ standard is more subtle and complex than this, but that
00275 // is the basic idea.
00276 //
00277 // Anyways ...
00278 //
00279 // nacl_bit_cast<> calls memcpy() which is blessed by the standard,
00280 // especially by the example in section 3.9 .  Also, of course,
00281 // nacl_bit_cast<> wraps up the nasty logic in one place.
00282 //
00283 // Fortunately memcpy() is very fast.  In optimized mode, with a
00284 // constant size, gcc 2.95.3, gcc 4.0.1, and msvc 7.1 produce inline
00285 // code with the minimal amount of data movement.  On a 32-bit system,
00286 // memcpy(d,s,4) compiles to one load and one store, and memcpy(d,s,8)
00287 // compiles to two loads and two stores.
00288 //
00289 // I tested this code with gcc 2.95.3, gcc 4.0.1, icc 8.1, and msvc 7.1.
00290 //
00291 // WARNING: if Dest or Source is a non-POD type, the result of the memcpy
00292 // is likely to surprise you.
00293 
00294 template <class Dest, class Source>
00295 inline Dest nacl_bit_cast(const Source& source) {
00296   // Compile time assertion: sizeof(Dest) == sizeof(Source)
00297   // A compile error here means your Dest and Source have different sizes.
00298   typedef char VerifySizesAreEqual[sizeof(Dest) == sizeof(Source) ? 1 : -1];
00299 
00300   Dest dest;
00301   memcpy(&dest, &source, sizeof(dest));
00302   return dest;
00303 }
00304 
00305 #endif  /* __cplusplus */
00306 
00307 #endif  /* NATIVE_CLIENT_SRC_INCLUDE_NACL_MACROS_H_ */
